title: Durga Ashtami 2015: Know about Ashtami Vrat, Pooja Vidhi, Katha & Naivedyam
text:
Durga Ashtami 2015: Know about Ashtami Vrat, Pooja Vidhi, Katha & Naivedyam By India.com News Desk on October 20, 2015 at 3:53 PM Comments Mumbai, Oct 20: Maha Durgashtami or Mahashtami is considered one of the most auspicious days of ten-day long Durga Puja festival. The Goddess Mahisasuramardini which means the Annihilator of the Buffalo Demon is worshiped on the eighth day. People observe fast or Ashtami Vrat or fast on this day in regards to Goddess Durga. Durga is considered as the deity of power, courage and strength. Fasting is believed to attain spiritual needs of a person. This year Ashtami Tithi begins on October 20 and ends on October 21. Durgashtami falls in the month of Ashwin when the nine days Shardiya Navaratri are celebrated. Durga Puja festival is celebrated from the sixth to tenth day of bright lunar fortnight. Timings for Ashtami Vrat are as follows: Ashtami Tithi Begins = 14:23 on October 20, 2015 Ashtami Tithi Ends = 13:29 on October 21, 2015 Fasting is by most Hindu devotees across India. In norther India, many people fast for all nine days of Durga Puja. The puja being a ritual, most people have been following it as a tradition since centuries. People break their fast by offering food to beggars. Traditionally, people also worship young girls as they are regarded as ‘kanya avatar’ of Goddess Durga. However, western India follows a completely different ritual during fast. They sow barley seeds to sprout which is later offered as a prasad to devotees. (Also Read: Know the Durga Ashtami Puja Muhurat, Puja Vidhi & auspicious timings of Maha Ashtami) The day is celebrated to show the power of Maa Durga who killed evil demon Mahishasura. The festival is also celebrated in Nepal and Bhutan. Pooja Vidhi People wake up early in the morning to perform Navratri pooja . Devotees light ‘Akhand Jyoti’ in front of Durga’s sculpture on this day. According to beliefs people do not leave their house vacant on this day. Devotees also offer incense ticks, coconut and ring the bells or blow the shank to invoke the Goddess. Katha Accounts from Sri Satya Naranaya Katha is read in temples and other places where the pooja is held. It is believed ne must stick to the promise given to the Lord in exchange of the desire fulfilled by his grace. One is not to ignore or forget the Lord’s Grace. Naivedyam Naivedyam is the food offerings offered to the Goddess Durga during Navratri. In South Indian nine types of food are offered to the Goddess on the nine different days.
